abstract.text: The OPERA experiment discovered muon neutrino into tau neutrino oscillations in appearance mode, detecting tau leptons by means of nuclear emulsion films.
The apparatus was also endowed with electronic detectors with tracking capability, such as scintillator strips and resistive plate chambers.
Because of its location, in the underground Gran Sasso laboratory, under 3800 m.w.e., the OPERA detector has also been used as an observatory for TeV muons produced by cosmic rays in the atmosphere.
In this paper the measurement of the single muon flux modulation and of its correlation with the seasonal variation of the atmospheric temperature are reported.

body_text.text: Contents
1 Introduction
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: Muons observed in underground laboratories are produced mainly in decays of pions and kaons generated by the interaction of primary cosmic rays with the upper atmosphere.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: Since muons loose energy crossing the rock overburden, only high energy muons can be detected, with an energy threshold depending on depth, usually expressed in metre water equivalent (m.w.e.).
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: It is known that the flux of atmospheric muons detected deep underground shows seasonal time variations correlated with the temperature of the stratosphere, where the primary cosmic rays interact [1].
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: This effect has been reported by other experiments at the underground Gran Sasso Laboratory (LNGS) (MACRO [2][3][4], LVD [5], Borexino [6,7] and GERDA [8]) and elsewhere (AMANDA [9], IceCube [10], MINOS [11,12], Double Chooz [13] and Daya Bay [14]).
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: An increase in temperature of the stratosphere, indeed, causes a decrease of the air density, thus reducing the chance of π, K mesons to interact, and resulting in a larger fraction decaying into muons.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: So, the atmospheric muon rate changes during the year increasing in summer and decreasing in winter.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The variation can be modeled as a sinusoidal function, which is only a first order approximation since the average temperature is not precisely constant over the years and short term effects occur, leading to local maxima and minima, like the "sudden stratospheric warming" events [15].
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The OPERA experiment [16] discovered ν µ into ν τ oscillations in appearance mode using the CERN Neutrino to Gran Sasso (CNGS) beam [17,18].
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The experiment was located in the Hall C of LNGS laboratory, at 3800 m.w.e. depth.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: To identify ν τ Charged Current interactions, the Emulsion Cloud Chamber technique was used, with 1 mm lead sheets alternated with nuclear emulsion films, for a total target mass of about 1.2 kt.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: Lead and emulsions were organised into units called "bricks".
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The detector was divided into two identical Super-Modules (SM), each made of a target section, composed by 31 brick walls interleaved with target tracker layers to locate bricks with neutrino interactions, and of a muon spectrometer to optimise the muon identification probability and to measure momentum and charge.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: In each SM, the Target Tracker (TT) [19] consisted of 31 pairs of orthogonal planes made of 2.6 cm wide scintillator strips, read-out by means of WLS fibers.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The fibers from the 6.7 m long strips were collected into four groups of 64 and coupled to 64-channel Hamamatsu H7546 photomultipliers.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The muon spectrometers were made by an iron-core dipole magnet with drift tubes used as precision trackers and 22 layers of resistive plate chambers (RPC) [20] inside the magnetised iron.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The 2D read-out was performed by means of 2.6 cm pitch and 8 m long vertical strips, which measured the coordinate in the bending plane, and 3.5 cm pitch and 8.7 m long horizontal strips, measuring the orthogonal coordinate.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The analysis presented here is based on TT and RPC data recorded during about five years from January 2008 to March 2013.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: In the TT, the trigger condition required either hits in the horizontal and vertical views of at least two planes or at least 10 hits in a single plane with a signal greater than 30 photo-electrons for 2008 and 2009 runs; from 2010 up to 2013 the latter requirements were lowered to 4 hits and 10 photo-electrons, respectively.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: Data from the RPCs of each spectrometer were acquired in presence of at least 3 planes fired in a time window of 200 ns.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: Events were recorded in presence of at least 5 TT and/or RPC hits in each view, horizontal and vertical, within a time window of 500 ns.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: The TT systems were operative during most of the time in the considered years, while the RPCs had a lower run-time, being operative only during CNGS runs and switched off during the CNGS winter shutdowns.
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: More details about the electronic detectors used for the cosmic ray muon analysis can be found in [16].
body_text.section: Contents

body_text.text: Atmospheric temperature modulation
To measure the atmospheric temperature modulation, we have used data from the European Center for Medium-range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) [25].
body_text.section: Atmospheric temperature modulation

body_text.text: The center provides temperature values at different altitudes above given locations, obtained by means of interpolations based on measurements of various kinds around the planet and on a global atmospheric model.
body_text.section: Atmospheric temperature modulation

body_text.text: The coordinates are those used in [6]: 13.5333 • E, 42.4275 • N. The atmospheric temperature is provided at 37 discrete pressure levels ranging from 1 to 1000 hPa four times in each day (0.00 h, 6.00 h, 12.00 h and 18.00 h).
body_text.section: Atmospheric temperature modulation

body_text.text: Averaging these temperature values using weights accounting for the production of pions and kaons at different altitudes (see Appendix A), the effective atmospheric temperature T ef f has been calculated four times a day.
body_text.section: Atmospheric temperature modulation

body_text.text: The four measurements are then averaged and the variance used as an estimate of the uncertainty on the mean value.

body_text.text: Conclusions

In this paper we report on studies about the seasonal variation of the flux of single muons generated in cosmic rays interactions in the high atmosphere, as measured by the OPERA electronic detectors located in the LNGS underground laboratory.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The observed dependence is approximated by a constant flux with the presence of a (1.55±0.08)% modulated component with one year period and maximum at (186 ± 3 stat ± 5 sys ) day, corresponding to July 5.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: An effective atmospheric temperature has been defined as the average of the temperatures of the air column above the experimental site, weighted by the production probability of high energy muons, detectable by our underground detector.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The effective atmospheric temperature shows a time variation similar to cosmic ray rate changes.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: A cross correlation function based study has demonstrated the presence of short term deviations from a pure yearly modulated model, both in the cosmic ray flux and in the effective temperature.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: These short term deviations and the modulated components appear to be simultaneous in the two time series.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The effective atmospheric temperature and muon rate variations are positively correlated (R = 0.50).
body_text.section: Conclusions
